Introduction

Vulvar cancer is a malignancy of the female external genitalia, which include the labia majora and minora, vaginal introitus, clitoris, and urethral meatus.  The most common histologic type is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), which typically presents in older women with persistent human papillomavirus (HPV) infection or lichen sclerosus.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The most common type of vulvar cancer is SCC, which can develop via 2 independent mechanisms:



  • HPV-dependent (most common):  persistent HPV infection (particularly with high-risk types 16 and 18) causes squamous cell mutations via integration and expression of viral oncogenes (
    figure 1
    ).  Oncogenesis from high-risk HPV is attributed to viral proteins E6 and E7, which inhibit p53 and Rb, leading to unregulated cell proliferation, dysplasia, and malignant transformation.  Risk factors for HPV-related cancer are related to:

    • Increased exposure to HPV, usually involving high-risk sexual activity (eg, multiple sexual partners, early age at onset of sexual activity)
    • Inability to clear persistent HPV infection due to:
      • Chronic tobacco use
      • Immunodeficiency (eg, HIV)
      • Vulvar or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia
      • Prior cervical cancer
  • HPV-independent (less common):  The pathogenesis of vulvar SCC is related to chronic inflammatory or autoimmune processes associated with vulvar dermatoses.  The greatest risk factor is lichen sclerosus.

Clinical presentation



Patients with vulvar cancer are typically older; the average age of diagnosis is 68.  The classic presentation includes:



  • A unifocal, friable plaque or ulcer on the labia majus, which can cause bleeding with intercourse or wiping
  • Vulvar pruritus or pain, which can cause dyspareunia
  • Painless, unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy, which suggests an advanced cancer stage


However, many patients are asymptomatic and have a lesion identified on routine examination.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of vulvar cancer requires a biopsy of the lesion (eg, punch biopsy) and histopathologic evaluation, which distinguishes between benign (eg, lichen sclerosus) and neoplastic lesions.  In addition, it helps further differentiate between noninvasive neoplasia (eg, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions) and invasive cancer.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of vulvar SCC includes both benign and malignant lesions of the vulva.

Benign vulvar lesions



  • Lichen sclerosus:  a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by white, patchy areas of thin skin that may be pruritic or painful.  It can mimic the appearance of vulvar cancer but typically lacks ulceration or raised borders.
  • Lichen planus:  an inflammatory disorder that can affect the vulva.  It typically presents with vulvar pain with either erosive, glazed lesions with white striae (ie, Wickham striae) or small purple papules.
  • Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata):  typically present as painless, soft, pink or flesh-colored growths on the vulva.

Other malignant vulvar lesions



  • Melanoma:  can occur on the vulva but typically presents as pigmented lesions with irregular borders.
  • Paget disease of the vulva:  a rare form of intraepithelial adenocarcinoma that presents with eczematous, erythematous patches or plaques on the vulva.
  • Bartholin gland carcinoma:  a rare vulvar lesion that typically presents as an immobile mass at the 4 and 8 o'clock positions at the vaginal introitus.

Management



Patients with biopsy-proven vulvar cancer require further evaluation to determine the cancer stage.



Vulvar cancer staging (eg, tumor size, depth of invasion, local extension, lymph node involvement) is via both clinical and surgical approaches and includes:



  • Examination of the cervix, vagina, and perianal skin to evaluate for disease extension (local invasion) and possible concomitant, HPV-related malignancy in these regions.
  • MRI or CT scan of the pelvis to determine tumor size, local invasion, and lymph node involvement.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy to determine whether vulvar carcinoma has spread from the primary site to the regional lymph nodes via lymphatic drainage.  Initial staging assesses for tumor spread to the sentinel lymph nodes (ie, the first lymph nodes to drain the primary tumor site).  The sentinel lymph nodes biopsied for vulvar SCC are the inguinofemoral nodes, which consist of a superficial inguinal node and a deeper femoral node.


The majority of patients with vulvar SCC are treated with surgery (eg, wide local excision Â± lymph node dissection based on lymph node involvement) and possible adjuvant therapy (ie, radiation therapy, chemotherapy).  Medical management is pursued only in patients with unresectable disease, medical comorbidities that preclude surgery, or distant metastatic disease.



Long-term follow-up is needed for posttreatment surveillance due to the risk for recurrent disease.

Prognosis



The prognosis for vulvar SCC depends on the stage of disease.  The greatest prognostic factor is inguinal and/or femoral lymph node involvement.  Lesions confined to the primary site usually have a good prognosis.  In contrast, locally advanced or metastatic disease carries a poorer prognosis.



Other important factors include patient age and overall health.  Early detection and treatment are associated with improved outcomes.

Prevention

Summary



Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulvar cancer (
